recipes.name: Fish and Chips
ingredients: 1 kg Potatoes (Russet or Maris Piper), cut into 1cm chips
4 x 175g White fish fillets (Cod or Haddock), skinless and boneless
2 Litres Vegetable or peanut oil (for frying)
instructions: Prepare the Chips (First Fry): Rinse chips in cold water and pat dry. Heat oil to 130°C (266°F). Fry chips in batches for 5-8 minutes until soft but not browned. Remove and drain. Increase oil temperature to 180°C (356°F).
Prepare the Batter: Whisk flour, baking powder, and a pinch of salt/pepper. Gradually whisk in the cold beer until smooth. Keep cold.

Fry the Fish: Pat fish fillets dry. Dust lightly in flour, then dip into the batter. Carefully lower the fish into the 180°C (356°F) oil. Fry for 5-8 minutes, turning occasionally, until golden brown and flaky. Remove and drain.
Prepare the Chips (Second Fry): Return the blanched chips to the 180°C (356°F) oil. Fry for 2-4 minutes until golden brown and crisp. Remove and drain.
Serve: Serve immediately with salt and malt vinegar.

recipes.name: Shepherd's Pie
instructions: Prepare the Mash: Peel and chop potatoes. Boil in salted water until tender. Drain well. Add butter and milk/cream, mash until smooth. Season and set aside.
Make the Filling: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Brown the minced lamb in a large pan, drain excess fat. Add onions and carrots; cook for 5 minutes until soft.

Create the Gravy: Stir in the flour and cook for 1 minute. Gradually pour in the stock and Worcestershire sauce, stirring constantly. Season well. Simmer for 10-15 minutes until thickened. Stir in the frozen peas.
Assemble and Bake: Spoon the lamb filling into a casserole dish. Carefully spoon the mashed potato on top, spreading evenly and raking the top with a fork for crisping.
Bake until Golden: Bake for 25-30 minutes, or until the filling is bubbling and the topping is golden brown. Rest for 5 minutes before serving.

recipes.name: Bangers and Mash
ingredients: 8 Quality pork sausages (Cumberland or Lincolnshire style)
1 tsp Balsamic vinegar or red wine (optional)
instructions: Cook the Sausages: Cook the sausages in a frying pan or oven until golden brown and cooked through (20-25 minutes). Set aside, retaining the pan drippings for the gravy.
Make the Mash: Peel and chop potatoes. Boil in salted water until tender. Drain well. Add butter and milk/cream. Mash until lump-free and creamy. Season and keep warm.
Prepare the Onion Gravy: In the same pan (with drippings), gently cook the sliced onions over medium-low heat for 15-20 minutes until deeply golden brown and caramelized.

Thicken the Gravy: Stir the flour into the caramelized onions and cook for 1 minute. Gradually pour in the beef stock, stirring constantly. Add vinegar (if using) and season. Simmer until the gravy has thickened (5-10 minutes).
Serve: Spoon mash onto plates, top with two sausages, and smother generously with the rich onion gravy.

recipes.name: Sticky Toffee Pudding
ingredients: For the Toffee Sauce: 200ml Double Cream
For the Toffee Sauce: 100g Dark Muscovado Sugar
instructions: Prepare the Dates: Place dates and bicarbonate of soda in a bowl. Pour over the boiling water. Stir and leave to cool for 15 minutes.
Make the Pudding Batter: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F) and grease a baking dish. Cream butter and brown sugar until fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Fold in the flour until just combined.
Combine and Bake: Gently stir in the date mixture (including the liquid). Pour the batter into the prepared dish. Bake for 40-45 minutes until risen and cooked through.
Make the Sauce: Combine cream, muscovado sugar, and butter in a saucepan. Bring to a gentle boil, stirring until the sugar dissolves. Simmer for 3-5 minutes until thickened slightly.

Serve: Once the pudding is out of the oven, use a skewer to poke holes all over the top. Pour about half of the warm toffee sauce over the pudding. Serve warm with the remaining sauce and custard or ice cream.

recipes.name: Victoria Sponge Cake
ingredients: For the filling: 150ml Double cream (whipped) OR Vanilla Buttercream (100g butter, 200g icing sugar, 1 tsp vanilla)
instructions: Prepare the Batter: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease and line two 20cm sandwich tins. Cream the butter and sugar until pale and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time.
Bake the Sponges: Gently fold in the sifted flour until just combined, being careful not to overmix. Divide the batter evenly between the two prepared tins and smooth the tops.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the cakes are golden and spring back when lightly touched. Turn out onto a wire rack and allow to cool completely.
Assemble: Place one cooled sponge onto a serving plate. Spread generously with jam, then top with either fresh whipped cream or a layer of vanilla buttercream.
Finish: Place the second sponge gently on top. Dust the cake with icing sugar before serving.

recipes.name: Full English Breakfast
instructions: Cook the Sausages and Bacon: Cook the sausages in a pan or under the grill until brown and cooked through (about 20 mins). Add the bacon towards the end of the sausage cooking time. Keep warm.
Cook Vegetables and Black Pudding: Fry the mushroom slices and tomato halves in the same pan until soft. Fry the black pudding slice for 3-4 minutes per side. Keep warm.
Prepare Beans and Eggs: Heat the baked beans in a saucepan. Fry or scramble the eggs to your preference. If frying, use the leftover fat in the pan for flavor.
Prepare the Bread: Toast the bread or fry it quickly in the pan fat until golden brown (fried bread).
Assemble and Serve: Pile all the components neatly onto a single plate. Serve immediately with tea or coffee.

recipes.name: Beef Wellington
ingredients: 400g Mixed mushrooms (e.g., Chestnut, Shiitake), for Duxelles
instructions: Sear the Beef: Season the beef fillet generously. Sear it on all sides in a hot pan with oil for 30-60 seconds per side. Remove and brush immediately with Dijon mustard. Cool completely.

Make the Duxelles: Pulse mushrooms, shallots, and thyme in a food processor until finely chopped. Cook this mixture in a dry pan until all moisture has evaporated (about 10-15 minutes). Season and cool completely.

Assemble the Wellington: Lay a large sheet of cling film on your work surface. Overlap the slices of Prosciutto on the cling film to form a rectangle slightly wider than the beef. Spread the mushroom duxelles evenly over the ham.

Wrap the Beef: Place the cooled beef fillet at the bottom edge of the mushroom/ham layer. Using the cling film, tightly roll the ham and duxelles around the fillet. Twist the ends of the cling film to create a tight cylinder. Chill for 30 minutes.

Encase in Pastry: Roll out the puff pastry large enough to wrap the beef. Remove the cling film from the beef. Brush the edges of the pastry with egg wash. Place the beef on the pastry and wrap it tightly, trimming excess pastry. Seal the edges and chill for another 30 minutes.

Bake: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Brush the Wellington all over with the remaining egg wash. Score the pastry lightly. Bake for 30-45 minutes until the pastry is golden brown. For medium-rare, the internal temperature should be around 55-60°C (130-140°F). Rest for 10-15 minutes before slicing and serving.

recipes.name: Cornish Pasty
ingredients: 400g Skirt beef, cut into small cubes (approx 1cm)
instructions: Prepare the Filling: In a large bowl, mix the cubed beef, potato, swede, and onion. Season very generously with salt and pepper (the traditional filling is always raw).
Prepare the Pastry: Divide the pastry into 4 equal pieces and roll each into a circle approximately 20-25cm in diameter. Dust with flour.

Assemble the Pasty: Place a quarter of the raw filling mixture onto one half of each pastry circle, leaving a 2cm border. Start the filling with a layer of potato, then the meat, followed by the onion and swede. Dot with a small amount of butter (optional but recommended).

Seal and Crimp: Brush the pastry border with water or egg wash. Fold the empty side of the pastry over the filling to form a semi-circle. Crimp the edges tightly together along the side to create the distinctive ridge. Ensure it is completely sealed to keep the juices in.

Bake: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Brush the pasties with egg wash. Place on a baking tray and bake for 10 minutes, then reduce the heat to 160°C (325°F) and bake for another 45-50 minutes, until the pastry is golden brown and the filling is cooked through.

recipes.name: Lancashire Hotpot
ingredients: 1 kg Lamb shoulder or neck fillet, cut into 3cm cubes (Mutton traditionally)
2 kg Potatoes (Maris Piper or King Edward), thinly sliced (approx 3mm)
50g Butter or lamb fat (for potato topping)
instructions: Prepare the Base: Preheat oven to 160°C (325°F). Season the lamb cubes and toss with the flour. In a large pan, sear the lamb cubes in a little fat until browned on all sides. Remove the lamb and set aside.
Layer the Pot: Layer the bottom of a deep casserole dish with half of the sliced onions and carrots. Add the seared lamb on top, followed by the remaining onions and carrots. Season lightly.
Add Liquid: In the same pan, heat the stock and Worcestershire sauce. Pour the liquid over the lamb mixture. It should just cover the meat (add more water/stock if needed).
Add Potato Topping: Arrange the thinly sliced potatoes in overlapping concentric circles on top of the meat and vegetables. Brush the potatoes with melted butter or fat and season generously.

Slow Cook: Cover the dish tightly with a lid or foil. Cook for 1.5 - 2 hours. Remove the lid/foil and cook for a further 30-45 minutes until the potato topping is golden brown and the lamb is tender. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Toad in the Hole
ingredients: 3-4 tbsp Beef dripping, lard, or vegetable oil (for baking)
instructions: Prepare the Batter: Sift the flour into a bowl and make a well in the center. Whisk the eggs and milk together. Gradually pour the wet mixture into the flour, whisking continuously until you have a smooth, thin batter (like single cream). Season well. Allow the batter to rest in the fridge for at least 30 minutes, or up to 2 hours.
Preheat the Oven: Preheat your oven to 220°C (425°F). Pour the dripping or oil into a deep roasting tin (approx. 25x35cm) and place it in the oven for 10-15 minutes until the fat is smoking hot.
Sear the Sausages: Meanwhile, sear the sausages in a frying pan until they are nicely browned on all sides (they don't need to be fully cooked).
Combine and Bake: Carefully remove the hot tin from the oven. Arrange the seared sausages in the hot fat. Pour the rested batter evenly over the sausages and fat.

Bake: Return the tin immediately to the hot oven. Bake for 25-30 minutes. DO NOT open the oven door during this time, or the pudding will collapse. The 'Toad in the Hole' should be well-risen, golden brown, and crisp. Serve immediately with onion gravy (not included in ingredients but recommended).

recipes.name: Beef Wellington (Reduced Serving)
ingredients: 400g Mixed mushrooms (e.g., Chestnut, Shiitake), for Duxelles
instructions: Sear the Beef: Season the beef fillet generously. Sear it on all sides in a hot pan with oil for 30-60 seconds per side. Remove and brush immediately with Dijon mustard. Cool completely.

Make the Duxelles: Pulse mushrooms, shallots, and thyme in a food processor until finely chopped. Cook this mixture in a dry pan until all moisture has evaporated (about 10-15 minutes). Season and cool completely.

Assemble the Wellington: Lay a large sheet of cling film on your work surface. Overlap the slices of Prosciutto on the cling film to form a rectangle slightly wider than the beef. Spread the mushroom duxelles evenly over the ham.

Wrap the Beef: Place the cooled beef fillet at the bottom edge of the mushroom/ham layer. Using the cling film, tightly roll the ham and duxelles around the fillet. Twist the ends of the cling film to create a tight cylinder. Chill for 30 minutes.

Encase in Pastry: Roll out the puff pastry large enough to wrap the beef. Remove the cling film from the beef. Brush the edges of the pastry with egg wash. Place the beef on the pastry and wrap it tightly, trimming excess pastry. Seal the edges and chill for another 30 minutes.

Bake: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Brush the Wellington all over with the remaining egg wash. Score the pastry lightly. Bake for 30-45 minutes until the pastry is golden brown. For medium-rare, the internal temperature should be around 55-60°C (130-140°F). Rest for 10-15 minutes before slicing and serving.

recipes.name: Christmas Pudding
instructions: Mix Dry Ingredients: In a large bowl, mix the suet, breadcrumbs, flour, sugar, mixed spice, and nutmeg. Stir in the dried mixed fruit, peel, and cherries.

Add Wet Ingredients: Add the beaten egg and the stout/brandy to the bowl. Stir the mixture thoroughly until everything is well combined. This is the stage for traditionally making a wish ('Stir-up Sunday').

Prepare for Steaming: Grease a 1.2 litre pudding basin. Spoon the mixture into the basin, packing it down well. Cover the top with a circle of parchment paper, then cover tightly with a layer of pleated foil and secure it with string (this allows for expansion).

Steam (The Long Cook): Place the basin in a large pan with water halfway up the side of the bowl. Cover the pan with a tight lid. Bring the water to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Steam the pudding for 8 hours, topping up the water as necessary.

Storage and Reheating: Once cooked, allow to cool completely. Replace the foil and store in a cool, dark place. On Christmas Day, steam the pudding again for 2 hours to reheat. Serve flamed with warm brandy and custard or brandy butter.

recipes.name: Scotch Egg
ingredients: 400g Quality sausage meat (pork or pork and sage)
instructions: Prepare Eggs: Boil 4 eggs for 6-7 minutes (for soft yolk) or 8-10 minutes (for hard yolk). Immediately plunge into ice water. Peel and pat dry. Season the sausage meat well.

Wrap the Eggs: Divide the sausage meat into 4 equal portions. Flatten one portion between two pieces of cling film into a thin patty. Place a peeled egg in the center and carefully wrap the sausage meat around the egg, ensuring it is completely sealed and shaped into a ball.

Bread the Eggs: Set up a breading station with three shallow bowls: one with flour, one with the beaten egg, and one with the breadcrumbs. Roll each sausage-covered egg first in flour (dust off excess), then in the beaten egg, and finally coat thoroughly in the breadcrumbs.

Fry: Heat the oil in a deep saucepan or deep fryer to 170°C (340°F). Carefully lower the Scotch eggs into the hot oil (one or two at a time) and fry for 6-8 minutes, turning occasionally, until the sausage meat is cooked through and the coating is golden brown. Drain on kitchen paper.
Serve: Serve warm or cold, cut in half, with a relish or pickle.

recipes.name: Cottage Pie
ingredients: 1 kg Minced beef (traditionally used for Cottage Pie)
instructions: Prepare the Mash: Peel and chop potatoes. Boil in salted water until tender. Drain well. Add butter and milk/cream, mash until smooth. Season and set aside.
Make the Filling: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Brown the minced beef in a large pan, drain excess fat. Add onions and carrots; cook for 5 minutes until soft.

Create the Gravy: Stir in the flour and tomato puree, cook for 1 minute. Gradually pour in the beef stock, stirring constantly. Season well with salt and pepper. Simmer for 10-15 minutes until thickened. Stir in the frozen peas.
Assemble and Bake: Spoon the beef filling into a casserole dish. Carefully spoon the mashed potato on top, spreading evenly and raking the top with a fork for crisping.
Bake until Golden: Bake for 25-30 minutes, or until the filling is bubbling and the topping is golden brown. Rest for 5 minutes before serving.

recipes.name: Roast Beef and Yorkshire Pudding
ingredients: 1 kg Beef roasting joint (Sirloin or Topside)
For Yorkshire Puddings: 4 tbsp Beef dripping or vegetable oil (for baking)
instructions: Roast the Beef: Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F). Rub the beef with oil, salt, and pepper. Roast for 20 minutes, then reduce the heat to 180°C (350°F) and continue roasting for 10-15 minutes per 500g for medium-rare. Rest for 20 minutes under foil.
Make Yorkshire Pudding Batter: Whisk the flour and a pinch of salt. Gradually whisk in the eggs, then the milk until smooth. Leave to rest for at least 30 minutes (or up to 2 hours) in the fridge.

Cook the Yorkshire Puddings: Increase oven temperature back to 220°C (425°F). Place 1 tsp of beef dripping into each cup of a 12-hole muffin tin. Heat the tin in the oven until the fat is smoking hot (about 10 minutes).

Bake: Carefully remove the tin, pour the batter quickly into the hot fat (it should sizzle). Return immediately to the oven. Bake for 20-25 minutes until well-risen and golden brown. Serve immediately with the carved beef and gravy.

recipes.name: Steak and Kidney Pie
ingredients: 750g Beef steak (chuck or braising steak), cubed
250g Beef or Lamb kidney, trimmed and cubed
instructions: Braise the Meat: Season the meat and toss with flour. Brown the steak and kidney in a little oil in batches. Add the onions and cook until softened. Return all meat to the pan.

Make the Gravy: Pour in the beef stock and Worcestershire sauce. Bring to a simmer, then cover and cook gently on the hob or in a 160°C (325°F) oven for 90 minutes, until the meat is very tender. Allow the filling to cool completely.
Assemble the Pie: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Pour the cooled filling into a deep pie dish. Roll out the pastry to cover the dish, making a slight overhang. Cut a small vent in the center.
Seal and Bake: Brush the rim of the dish with water and press the pastry lid firmly onto the edges to seal. Crimp the edges. Brush the entire surface with the beaten egg wash.
Bake: Bake for 30-40 minutes until the pastry is golden brown and the filling is bubbling hot. Rest for 10 minutes before serving.

recipes.name: Scones (Cream Tea)
ingredients: Accompaniments: Clotted cream and strawberry jam
instructions: Prepare Dough: Preheat oven to 220°C (425°F). Lightly grease a baking sheet. In a large bowl, rub the cold butter into the flour, salt, and baking powder until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs.

Mix and Knead: Stir in the caster sugar. Make a well, and pour in most of the milk. Mix quickly with a knife until you have a soft, sticky dough (add remaining milk if needed). Lightly bring the dough together with your hands.

Cut and Glaze: Lightly dust your work surface and pat the dough out to a thickness of about 4cm. Using a fluted cutter (5cm diameter), cut out the scones. Place them on the prepared baking sheet. Brush the tops with the beaten egg (do not let the egg wash drip down the sides).
Bake: Bake for 12-15 minutes until well-risen and golden brown. Cool slightly on a wire rack. Serve warm, split in half, with jam and a generous dollop of clotted cream.

recipes.name: Eccles Cake
instructions: Make the Filling: Melt the butter in a pan. Remove from heat and stir in the currants, mixed peel, brown sugar, mixed spice, and water. Stir well and allow to cool completely.
Prepare Pastry Rounds: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Roll out the puff pastry thinly (about 3mm). Cut out 8 circles, each about 10cm in diameter.

Fill and Seal: Place a spoonful of the cooled filling in the center of each pastry circle. Draw the edges of the pastry up over the filling to completely enclose it, pinching the top firmly to seal it shut.

Shape and Bake: Turn the cakes over so the sealed side is underneath. Flatten them gently with a rolling pin into a round disc. Brush the top with egg white and sprinkle generously with caster sugar. Make three small slits in the top of each cake with a sharp knife.
Bake for 12-15 minutes until the pastry is golden brown and flaky. Serve warm or cold.

recipes.name: Cullen Skink
instructions: Poach the Fish: Place the smoked haddock in a large pan with the milk and stock/water. Bring to a gentle simmer. Poach for 5-8 minutes until the fish flakes easily. Remove the fish, reserving the liquid. Flake the fish into large pieces and discard any skin or bones.
Sauté Vegetables: In a separate large pan, melt the butter and gently cook the chopped onion until soft (about 5 minutes). Add the diced potatoes and stir.
Simmer the Soup: Pour the reserved poaching liquid over the onions and potatoes. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes until the potatoes are tender.

Finish and Serve: Gently stir in the flaked haddock. Reheat the soup but do not let it boil after the fish is added. Season with salt and generous white pepper. Serve hot, garnished with fresh parsley and crusty bread.

recipes.name: Welsh Rarebit
ingredients: 2 Large slices of thick bread (Sourdough or country loaf)
50ml Ale or Stout (optional, use milk if skipping)
1 tsp English Mustard powder or paste
1 tsp Worcestershire sauce (omit for strict vegetarian)
instructions: Prepare the Toast: Toast the bread lightly under the grill or in a toaster and keep warm.

Make the Rarebit Sauce: In a small saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Stir in the flour to form a roux, and cook for 1 minute. Gradually add the milk (and ale, if using), stirring constantly to form a thick sauce.

Add Cheese and Seasoning: Remove the pan from the heat. Stir in the grated cheese until melted and smooth. Stir in the mustard, Worcestershire sauce, and cayenne pepper (if using). Season well with salt and pepper.

Grill: Spread the rarebit sauce generously over the lightly toasted bread. Place the slices under a preheated hot grill for 2-4 minutes, or until the cheese topping is bubbling, golden brown, and slightly blistered. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Pork Pie
ingredients: 1 tsp Salt and 1/2 tsp pepper (generous seasoning)
instructions: Make Hot Water Crust Pastry: In a saucepan, bring the water and lard to a boil. Sift the flour and a pinch of salt into a large bowl. Pour the hot liquid over the flour and quickly mix with a wooden spoon until a ball of dough forms. Knead lightly and keep warm.
Prepare Filling: Mix the minced pork thoroughly with the salt, pepper, nutmeg, and mace. Keep cold.

Assemble the Pie: Reserve about 1/3 of the pastry for the lids. Use the remaining 2/3 to line four small pie tins or a 15cm cake tin, pressing it up the sides. Fill the pastry case with the seasoned meat, packing it down tightly.

Cover and Bake: Roll out the reserved pastry for the lids. Brush the rim of the base with egg wash and cover with the lid, crimping to seal. Cut a small hole in the center of the lid. Brush the entire pie with egg wash.
Bake: Bake at 180°C (350°F) for 1.5 - 2 hours until golden brown. Cool completely.

Add Jelly: Once cool, heat the pork stock and stir in 1 tbsp of gelatin powder (or use pre-made stock jelly). Pour the liquid into the hole in the pie lid until the pie is full. Refrigerate overnight until the jelly is set.

recipes.name: Treacle Tart
instructions: Prepare the Case: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Roll out the pastry and use it to line a 23cm tart tin. Trim the edges and prick the base all over with a fork. Chill for 10 minutes.
Make the Filling: In a bowl, combine the golden syrup, melted butter, lemon zest, and lemon juice. Stir well.
Assemble the Tart: Gently fold in the fresh breadcrumbs until they are evenly coated in the syrup mixture. Pour the filling into the chilled pastry case, smoothing the top.

Finish and Bake: You can decorate the top with lattice strips of leftover pastry (optional). Brush the pastry edges (and lattice, if used) with the beaten egg wash. Bake for 25-30 minutes until the pastry is golden and the filling is set but still slightly wobbly in the center. Serve warm with custard or cream.

recipes.name: Haggis, Neeps and Tatties
ingredients: 1 x 500g Traditional Haggis (usually sheep's pluck/offal, fat, oatmeal)
500g Tatties (Potatoes, e.g., Maris Piper), peeled and chopped
instructions: Cook the Haggis: Follow the instructions on the haggis packaging. Typically, wrap the haggis tightly in foil and simmer gently in a large pot of boiling water for 45-60 minutes per pound, or steam it.
Prepare Neeps and Tatties: Boil the chopped neeps in salted water until soft (about 20 minutes). Drain well and mash with a small amount of butter, milk (optional), salt, and pepper.
Prepare Tatties: Boil the chopped potatoes in separate salted water until soft (about 15 minutes). Drain well and mash with a small amount of butter, milk (optional), salt, and pepper.

Serve: Carefully remove the haggis from the foil. Slice open the casing and spoon the contents onto a plate. Serve alongside equal amounts of mashed neeps and mashed tatties. Traditionally accompanied by a dram of whisky.

recipes.name: Bakewell Tart
ingredients: For the Frangipane: 1 tsp Almond extract
Topping: Flaked almonds and Icing sugar for dusting
instructions: Prepare the Case: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Roll out the pastry and line a 23cm tart tin. Prick the base lightly with a fork and chill for 10 minutes. Spread the base evenly with the jam.
Make the Frangipane: Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Stir in the ground almonds and almond extract.
Assemble: Spoon the frangipane filling gently over the jam layer and spread evenly. Sprinkle the top generously with flaked almonds.
Bake: Bake for 40-45 minutes, or until the frangipane is golden brown and a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean. If the tart browns too quickly, cover lightly with foil.
Finish: Allow the tart to cool completely in the tin. Dust with a generous amount of icing sugar before slicing and serving.

recipes.name: Corned Beef Hash
ingredients: 500g Cooked potatoes (boiled or leftover roast), diced
instructions: Sauté Onions: Heat the oil/butter in a large frying pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and cook until soft and translucent (about 5 minutes).
Add Potatoes: Add the diced cooked potatoes to the pan. Increase the heat slightly and fry, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes start to crisp up and brown (about 8 minutes).
Add Corned Beef: Break the corned beef into the pan and mash it gently with the back of a spoon to combine it with the potatoes. Press the mixture down into an even layer to form a large 'cake'.
Crisp the Hash: Leave the hash to fry undisturbed for 5-8 minutes until a crisp, golden crust forms on the bottom. Flip the hash over in sections if necessary to brown the other side. Season well.
Serve: Fry the eggs separately until the whites are set and the yolks are runny. Serve the hash hot, topped with the fried eggs and a dash of Worcestershire sauce (optional).

recipes.name: Chelsea Buns
ingredients: For the Dough: 300g Strong white bread flour
For the Dough: 5g Fast action dried yeast
For the Dough: 50g Unsalted butter, softened
For the Filling: 75g Currants or mixed fruit
For the Glaze: 2 tbsp Apricot jam, warmed
instructions: Make the Dough: Mix the flour, yeast, and sugar in a bowl. Add the egg, warmed milk, and softened butter. Mix and knead for 10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Place in an oiled bowl, cover, and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled in size.

Shape the Buns: Punch down the dough and roll it out into a rectangle (approx. 40x25cm). Spread the softened butter over the dough, leaving a small border. Sprinkle evenly with brown sugar and currants/mixed fruit.

Roll and Cut: Roll the dough up tightly along the long edge, like a Swiss roll. Trim the ends and cut the roll into 9 equal slices. Place them cut-side up in a greased square baking tin (approx. 20x20cm).
Second Proof: Cover the tin and let the buns rise again in a warm place for 30 minutes.
Bake and Glaze: Preheat oven to 190°C (375°F). Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden brown. While still hot, brush generously with warmed apricot jam for a sticky glaze. Serve warm.

recipes.name: Hot Cross Buns
ingredients: For the Cross: 50g Plain flour mixed with 4 tbsp water
instructions: Make the Dough: Mix flour, sugar, yeast, spice, and lemon zest. Add the melted butter, beaten egg, and warmed milk. Mix and knead for 10 minutes until smooth. Add the dried fruit and knead briefly to incorporate.
First Proof: Place in an oiled bowl, cover, and let rise for 1-1.5 hours until doubled in size.
Shape and Second Proof: Punch down the dough and divide into 12 equal balls. Shape into round buns and place on a baking tray. Cover and let rise again for 30-45 minutes.
Add the Cross: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Mix the plain flour and water to form a smooth paste. Spoon the paste into a piping bag and pipe a cross onto the top of each bun.
Bake and Glaze: Bake for 15-20 minutes until golden brown. While hot, glaze with a warmed mixture of sugar and water (or apricot jam). Serve warm, traditionally toasted and buttered.

recipes.name: Bubble and Squeak
ingredients: 300g Cooked cabbage, Brussels sprouts, or other green veg, chopped (leftovers)
2 tbsp Butter or oil (or beef dripping, if non-vegetarian)
instructions: Combine Ingredients: In a large bowl, mix the cooked potatoes and chopped cooked vegetables (cabbage, sprouts, etc.) with the chopped onion (if using). Season generously with salt and pepper.
Heat the Pan: Heat the butter or oil in a large non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat. Add the potato and vegetable mixture to the pan.
Shape and Cook: Press the mixture down firmly with the back of a spoon to form a large, flat cake. Fry the cake undisturbed for 5-8 minutes until a crisp, golden brown crust has formed on the bottom.

Finish: Carefully flip the cake over (or cut it into quarters and flip) and press down again. Cook for another 5-8 minutes until the second side is also crisp and browned. Serve immediately alongside roast leftovers, bacon, or a fried egg.

recipes.name: Steak and Ale Pie
ingredients: 1 Bay leaf and 2 sprigs of thyme
instructions: Braise the Filling: Toss the cubed beef with the seasoned flour. Sear the meat in batches in a casserole dish with oil until browned. Remove the meat. Add onions and carrots and cook until soft (about 5 mins).

Make the Stew: Return the beef to the dish. Pour in the ale/stout and beef stock. Add the herbs, salt, and pepper. Bring to a simmer, then cover and cook gently in a 160°C (325°F) oven for 2 hours, until the meat is very tender. Cool completely.

Assemble the Pie: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Pour the cooled filling into a deep pie dish (use a pie funnel if available). Roll out the pastry to cover the dish, making a slight overhang. Cut a small vent in the center.
Seal and Bake: Brush the rim of the dish with water and press the pastry lid firmly onto the edges to seal. Crimp the edges. Brush the entire surface with the beaten egg wash.
Bake: Bake for 30-40 minutes until the pastry is golden brown and the filling is bubbling hot. Rest for 10 minutes before serving.

recipes.name: Fish Pie
ingredients: 500g Mixed fish fillets (Cod, Haddock, Salmon), cut into chunks
instructions: Poach the Fish: Place the fish chunks in a pan and cover with milk. Bring to a gentle simmer. Poach for 5 minutes until just cooked. Remove the fish with a slotted spoon, reserving the milk. Set the fish aside.

Make the Sauce: Melt the butter in a separate saucepan. Stir in the flour to form a roux, and cook for 1 minute. Gradually whisk in the reserved milk until smooth and thick. Stir in the chopped parsley and season generously. Remove from heat.
Assemble the Base: Gently combine the poached fish, prawns (if using), and chopped hard-boiled eggs (if using) into a pie dish. Pour the white sauce over the top.

Add Topping and Bake: Spoon the mashed potato on top of the sauce, spreading it evenly and raking the top with a fork. Bake in a preheated 200°C (400°F) oven for 25-30 minutes, until the topping is golden brown and the filling is bubbling hot.

recipes.name: Jellied Eels
ingredients: 1 kg Fresh eels, skinned and cut into 2-3cm pieces
instructions: Clean Eels: Wash the eel pieces thoroughly. Place the eel, water, sliced onion, bay leaf, thyme, lemon slices, salt, and pepper into a large saucepan.

Simmer: Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to a gentle simmer. Cook uncovered for 45-60 minutes, skimming off any impurities that rise to the surface. The eel should be tender, and the broth will have reduced and thickened naturally due to the collagen in the eel.
Cool and Remove Eels: Remove the pan from the heat. Stir in the white wine vinegar. Carefully remove the eel pieces with a slotted spoon and arrange them neatly in a shallow dish or individual bowls.

Set the Jelly: Strain the cooking liquid (broth) through a fine sieve into a clean bowl, discarding the solids. Pour the strained liquid over the arranged eel pieces. The liquid should be thick enough to set naturally.

Chill: Allow the dish to cool to room temperature, then place in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours, or until the liquid has set into a firm jelly. Serve cold, often with white pepper and malt vinegar.

recipes.name: Apple Crumble
ingredients: 750g Cooking apples (e.g., Bramley), peeled, cored, and sliced
For the Crumble: 100g Cold butter, cubed
For the Crumble: 100g Caster or light brown sugar
instructions: Prepare the Filling: Preheat oven to 190°C (375°F). Place the sliced apples in a pie dish. Sprinkle with 50g sugar and cinnamon (if using). Add 1 tbsp of water to the dish.
Make the Crumble: Rub the cold butter into the flour using your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse breadcrumbs. Stir in the 100g sugar.
Assemble and Bake: Spoon the crumble mixture evenly over the apple filling, ensuring the fruit is completely covered. Do not pack it down.
Bake: Bake for 30-40 minutes, until the topping is golden brown and crisp, and the apple filling is bubbling and soft. Serve warm with custard or cream.

recipes.name: Jam Roly-Poly
instructions: Make the Suet Pastry: Mix the flour, suet, and sugar in a large bowl. Gradually add the cold water, mixing with a knife until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms.

Roll and Fill: Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface. Roll or pat it out into a rectangle approximately 30x20cm. Spread the jam evenly over the surface, leaving a small border around the edges.
Roll and Seal: Starting from the long edge, tightly roll the pastry up like a Swiss roll. Pinch the ends together to seal them completely.
Steam: Lay the roll onto a large sheet of lightly flgreased parchment paper, then wrap it tightly in a layer of foil (leaving room for expansion). Twist the ends of the foil to seal.
Cook: Place the wrapped pudding in a steamer or on a trivet in a large pan of simmering water. Cover and steam for 1.5 hours. Serve immediately, sliced, with hot custard.

recipes.name: Spotted Dick
instructions: Make the Dough: Mix the flour, suet, currants, sugar, lemon zest, and salt in a bowl. Gradually add the milk or water, mixing with a knife to form a soft, slightly sticky dough.

Shape and Wrap: Pat the dough into a log shape (approx. 20cm long). Place the log onto a large sheet of lightly flgreased parchment paper, then wrap it tightly in a layer of foil (leaving room for expansion). Twist the ends of the foil to seal.

Steam: Place the wrapped pudding in a steamer or on a trivet in a large pan of simmering water. The water should come halfway up the side of the pudding. Cover and steam for 2 hours, topping up the water as needed.
Serve: Carefully unwrap the pudding. Slice thickly and serve warm with custard or a knob of butter.

recipes.name: Welsh Cakes
ingredients: Milk (optional, if needed to bring dough together)
instructions: Make the Dough: Sift the flour and mixed spice into a bowl. Rub the cold butter into the flour until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs.
Combine: Stir in the caster sugar and currants/sultanas. Add the beaten egg and mix until a firm dough forms (add a splash of milk if too dry).
Shape and Cut: Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface. Roll it out to a thickness of about 5mm. Use a round cutter (5-6cm) to cut out the cakes.
Cook on Griddle: Heat a lightly greased heavy-based frying pan or griddle over medium heat. Cook the Welsh Cakes in batches for 3-4 minutes on each side until golden brown and cooked through.
Serve: Remove the cakes from the griddle and immediately toss or sprinkle them with extra caster sugar. Serve warm or cold.

recipes.name: Irish Stew
ingredients: 1 kg Lamb or Mutton stewing cuts (traditional mutton is fattier)
1.5 kg Potatoes, peeled and thickly sliced/quartered
instructions: Prepare the Meat: Trim any excess fat from the lamb/mutton. Season generously with salt and pepper.

Layer the Pot: Layer the bottom of a large, heavy-based pot or casserole dish with a third of the sliced potatoes. Layer half of the meat, followed by half of the onions and carrots. Repeat the layers, finishing with a final layer of potatoes on top.
Add Liquid and Cook: Pour the stock over the vegetables and meat. The liquid should cover everything, or nearly cover the top layer of potatoes. Add the thyme sprigs. Bring to a simmer on the hob.

Slow Cook: Cover the pot tightly with a lid and transfer to an oven preheated to 150°C (300°F). Cook for 2 to 2.5 hours, or until the meat is falling apart and the potatoes are soft. The stew will naturally thicken.
Serve: Remove the thyme sprigs. Ladle into bowls and sprinkle generously with fresh chopped parsley.

recipes.name: Ploughman's Lunch
ingredients: 2 Thick slices of crusty bread or chunk of baguette
150g Chunk of mature Cheddar cheese or regional cheese (e.g., Stilton)
Small serving of salad (e.g., watercress or lettuce)
instructions: Assemble Bread and Cheese: Slice the bread thickly and spread with butter. Cut the chunk of cheese into a neat block.
Arrange Components: Arrange the bread, cheese, and a generous dollop of Branston pickle (or chutney) on a large plate or wooden board.
Add Pickles and Salad: Add the pickled onions and gherkins (if using). Garnish the plate with a small amount of fresh salad or watercress.
Serve: Traditionally served cold with a pint of ale.

recipes.name: Kidney Soup
ingredients: 500g Lamb or Beef kidneys, trimmed and diced
instructions: Prepare Kidneys: Rinse the kidneys well and pat dry. Dredge the pieces in 1 tbsp of the flour.
Sauté Vegetables: Heat oil/butter in a large pot. Add the onions, carrots, and celery; cook until soft (about 7 minutes). Remove vegetables and set aside.
Sear Kidneys: Increase heat and sear the kidney pieces quickly in the same pot until browned. Stir in the remaining flour and cook for 1 minute.
Simmer the Soup: Stir in the tomato puree, then gradually add the beef stock and Worcestershire sauce, scraping up any bits from the bottom. Return the vegetables to the pot. Season well.
Cook: Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer, partially covered, for 45-60 minutes, until the kidney is tender and the soup has thickened. Serve hot with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Bread and Butter Pudding
ingredients: 8-10 Slices of stale white bread, crusts removed (optional)
instructions: Prepare Bread: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Lightly butter a medium baking dish. Butter the slices of bread and cut them diagonally into triangles. Sprinkle the sultanas/currants into the dish.
Layer and Soak: Arrange the bread triangles, buttered side up, overlapping slightly in layers in the dish. Set aside.
Make Custard: Gently whisk together the milk, cream, eggs, and sugar until combined. Stir in a pinch of grated nutmeg.
Assemble and Bake: Pour the custard mixture slowly and evenly over the bread in the dish. Let the pudding stand for 20-30 minutes to allow the bread to soak up the custard.
Bake for 35-45 minutes until the custard is set but still slightly wobbly in the center, and the top is golden. Serve warm with cream or extra custard.

recipes.name: Bakewell Pudding (Original)
instructions: Prepare the Case: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Line a shallow 20cm round pie dish with the puff pastry, crimping the edges. Prick the base lightly. Spread the jam evenly over the base of the pastry.
Make the Filling: In a bowl, whisk the melted butter, caster sugar, and eggs until well combined. Stir in the almond extract and ground almonds.
Assemble and Bake: Pour the liquid custard filling carefully over the layer of jam. The filling will be quite thin.
Bake: Bake for 25-30 minutes, or until the pastry is golden and the custard filling is set and puffed slightly. The center should still be slightly soft.
Serve: Serve warm, dusted heavily with icing sugar. Unlike the tart, the pudding is meant to be soft and unset in the center when warm.

recipes.name: Chicken Tikka Masala
ingredients: 150g Natural yoghurt or coconut milk (for marinade)
1 tbsp Garam masala and Tandoori powder (for marinade)
For the Sauce: 1 Large onion, pureed
For the Sauce: 400g Canned chopped tomatoes
For the Sauce: 100ml Cream or cashew cream
For the Sauce: 1 tsp Kashmiri chili powder (for color)
instructions: Marinate and Cook Chicken: Marinate the cubed chicken in yoghurt/milk, ginger/garlic paste, garam masala, and tandoori powder for at least 30 minutes. Skewer and grill/broil the chicken until lightly charred (or cook in a hot pan). Set aside.

Make the Sauce Base: Heat oil in a pan. Sauté the pureed onion until golden brown (about 8 minutes). Add the remaining ginger/garlic paste, garam masala, and chili powder. Cook for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Simmer: Add the chopped tomatoes and a splash of water. Season with salt. Bring to a boil, then simmer gently for 15 minutes.
Finish the Masala: Stir in the cream (or substitute) and gently fold in the cooked chicken tikka pieces. Simmer for a final 5-10 minutes. Adjust seasoning and consistency.
Serve: Serve hot with pilau rice and naan bread.

recipes.name: Bara Brith (Welsh Tea Bread)
instructions: Soak the Fruit: Place the mixed fruit, sugar, lemon zest, and mixed spice in a bowl. Pour the hot tea over the mixture. Stir, cover, and leave to soak overnight (at least 12 hours) until the fruit has absorbed the liquid.

Make the Batter: Preheat oven to 160°C (325°F). Line a 2lb loaf tin with parchment paper. Stir the self-raising flour and the beaten egg into the soaked fruit mixture until just combined (do not overmix).

Bake: Pour the mixture into the prepared loaf tin, smoothing the top. Bake for 1.5 hours, or until a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean. If the top browns too quickly, cover it with foil.

Cool and Glaze: Remove from the oven and cool completely on a wire rack. For a classic finish, brush the warm loaf with a glaze made from dissolved sugar and water. Serve sliced, traditionally spread with butter.

recipes.name: Parkin (Yorkshire Gingerbread)
ingredients: 100g Lard or unsalted butter (for dairy-free, use vegetable shortening)
instructions: Combine Dry Ingredients: Preheat oven to 140°C (285°F). Grease and line a 20cm square cake tin. Combine the oatmeal, flour, bicarbonate of soda, ground ginger, and brown sugar in a large bowl.
Melt Wet Ingredients: In a saucepan, gently melt the lard/butter, black treacle, and golden syrup together until liquid and smooth. Do not boil.
Mix and Bake: Pour the melted mixture and the milk/water into the dry ingredients. Stir well until thoroughly combined. Pour the batter into the prepared tin.
Slow Bake and Cure: Bake for 50-60 minutes, until the cake is firm and springs back when lightly touched. It will be very soft when it comes out. Cool completely in the tin.
Cure: Parkin is traditionally best when wrapped tightly and stored in an airtight container for 2-3 days before serving, allowing the moisture to redistribute and soften the texture.

recipes.name: Trifle
ingredients: 1 Sponge flan base or slices of stale Madeira cake
150ml Sweet sherry or fruit juice (for soaking)
500g Fresh or canned fruit (e.g., raspberries, peaches)
instructions: Prepare Base: Cut the sponge cake into slices and spread liberally with jam. Arrange the slices neatly in the bottom of a large, clear trifle bowl. Drizzle evenly with sherry or juice.

Set Jelly: Prepare the jelly according to packet instructions. Pour half of the jelly mixture over the sponge cake base. Place a layer of fresh/canned fruit on top of the jelly. Chill for 1 hour or until the jelly is just set.

Add Custard: Pour the remaining jelly over the fruit (optional, for extra stability). Allow to set fully. Once set, pour the cooled custard over the jelly layer, ensuring the layers are separate. Chill for 1 hour.
Finish and Serve: Just before serving, whip the double cream until soft peaks form. Spoon or pipe the whipped cream over the custard layer. Decorate with flaked almonds or sprinkles. Serve cold.

recipes.name: Stargazy Pie
ingredients: 6-8 Whole Pilchards or Sardines (scaled and gutted, heads and tails intact)
instructions: Prepare Base and Filling: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Line a deep pie dish (approx. 20cm) with 2/3 of the pastry. Layer the bottom with the sliced onion and quartered hard-boiled eggs.
Make White Sauce: Melt the butter in a pan, stir in the flour, and cook for 1 minute. Gradually whisk in the milk/cream until thickened. Season well. Pour the sauce over the filling in the pie dish.

Arrange Fish: Arrange the whole fish within the dish. Position the fish so the heads are poking up through the pie crust and the tails are curled around the filling, mimicking the 'stargazing' effect.
Cover and Bake: Roll out the remaining pastry for the lid. Cut holes where the fish heads protrude. Seal the lid firmly to the pastry base around the rim. Brush the pastry with egg wash.
Bake: Bake for 15 minutes, then reduce the heat to 180°C (350°F) and bake for a further 40-45 minutes until the pastry is golden brown and the filling is bubbling hot. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Gammon, Egg, and Chips
ingredients: 500g Potatoes (Maris Piper or similar), cut into chips
instructions: Prepare the Chips: If using fresh potatoes, triple-cook the chips as per Fish and Chips recipe (blanch at 130°C, then fry at 180°C until golden). Alternatively, cook oven chips according to package instructions.
Cook Gammon: Heat a frying pan over medium-high heat. Add a little oil/fat. Cook the gammon steaks for 5-7 minutes per side, until fully cooked through. Remove and keep warm.
Cook Eggs: In the same pan (or a separate one), fry the eggs to your preferred doneness (sunny side up is traditional).
Optional Garnish: If using pineapple, quickly grill or fry the slices until slightly caramelized.
Serve: Arrange the hot chips on a plate. Top with the gammon steak and the fried egg. Serve immediately with a side of peas or pineapple.

recipes.name: Leek and Potato Soup (Cawl Cennin)
ingredients: 3 Large leeks (white and light green parts only), sliced and thoroughly washed
750g Potatoes (starchy, e.g., Maris Piper), peeled and diced
instructions: Sauté Vegetables: Melt the butter/oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the sliced leeks and chopped onion. Cook gently for 10-15 minutes until the leeks are very soft and translucent, but not browned.
Add Potatoes and Stock: Add the diced potatoes and stir well. Pour in the stock. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes, until the potatoes are completely tender.
Blend (Optional): For a chunky soup, leave as is. For a smooth soup, use a hand blender to blend the soup until smooth. Return the soup to the pot.
Finish: Stir in the milk/cream (if using). Reheat gently, stirring constantly. Season well with salt and white pepper. Serve hot with crusty bread.

recipes.name: Chicken and Mushroom Pie
instructions: Make the Filling: Melt the butter in a pan. Sauté the chopped onion and mushrooms until soft. Add the cubed chicken and cook until sealed.

Make the Sauce: Stir in the flour and cook for 1 minute. Gradually whisk in the chicken stock, followed by the milk/cream, stirring until the sauce is smooth and thick. Simmer for 10 minutes until the chicken is cooked through. Season well. Cool the filling completely.
Assemble the Pie: Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Pour the cooled filling into a deep pie dish (approx. 20cm). Roll out the puff pastry to cover the dish.
Seal and Bake: Brush the rim of the dish with water and press the pastry lid firmly onto the edges. Crimp the edges. Cut a small vent in the center. Brush the surface with the beaten egg wash.
Bake: Bake for 30-40 minutes until the pastry is golden brown and flaky, and the filling is bubbling hot. Rest for 5 minutes before serving.

recipes.name: Singin' Hinnies
instructions: Make the Dough: Sift the flour and salt into a bowl. Rub in the cold butter and lard/shortening until the mixture resembles coarse breadcrumbs. Stir in the sugar and currants/raisins.
Combine: Add the milk gradually and mix with a knife until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms. Bring the dough together quickly with your hands.
Shape and Cut: Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface. Roll or pat it out to a thickness of about 1.5cm. Use a round cutter (5cm diameter) to cut out the cakes. Do not twist the cutter.

Cook on Griddle: Heat a heavy-based frying pan or griddle over medium-low heat (do not grease the pan). Cook the cakes in batches for 8-10 minutes on each side until golden brown, puffed slightly, and cooked through. They should make a 'singing' sound as the fat melts and sizzles.
Serve: Serve warm, split and buttered, or with jam.

recipes.name: Coronation Chicken
ingredients: 500g Cooked chicken breast (poached or roasted), shredded or cubed
instructions: Prepare the Chicken: Ensure the cooked chicken is cold. Shred or chop it into bite-sized pieces.

Make the Sauce Base: In a small saucepan, gently heat the curry powder for 1 minute to release the flavor. Stir in the tomato puree, mango chutney, and 1 tbsp of water. Bring to a gentle simmer and cook for 2 minutes. Remove from heat and cool completely.
Combine: In a large bowl, mix the cooled sauce with the mayonnaise and double cream/yoghurt. Season well with salt and pepper.
Assemble: Gently fold the cooked chicken, sultanas/apricots, and flaked almonds (if using) into the sauce until the chicken is completely coated.
Serve: Chill for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld. Serve cold, typically in sandwiches, jacket potatoes, or with salad.

recipes.name: Kedgeree
instructions: Cook Rice and Fish: Cook the basmati rice until fluffy. Poach the smoked haddock in the milk and a splash of water for 5-8 minutes until tender. Remove the fish, flake it, and reserve the milk. Quarter the hard-boiled eggs.
Sauté Spices: Melt the butter in a large pan. Add the chopped onion and cook until soft (5 minutes). Stir in the curry powder and cook for 1 minute until fragrant.
Combine: Add the cooked rice to the pan and stir to coat it evenly in the spice mixture. Pour in the reserved milk/poaching liquid and stir quickly until absorbed.

Finish and Serve: Gently fold in the flaked haddock and most of the chopped parsley. Season well. Reheat gently. Serve immediately, garnished with the quartered hard-boiled eggs and a squeeze of lemon juice.
